section.title: Add a multi-factor authentication enforcement policy to Rackspace Cloud accounts
section.para: Rackspace Cloud account administrators can configure enforcement settings for multi-factor authentication across a domain.
Rackspace Cloud account administrators can configure enforcement settings for multi-factor authentication across a domain and customize them at the user level.

important.para: To configure domain-level enforcment, your Administrator account must be configured to use multi-factor authentication. See Set up multi-factor authentication via mobile phone.
To configure domain-level enforcment, your Administrator account must be configured to use multi-factor authentication by using a mobile phone or ..

section.para: To set domain level enforcement, use the update domain settings for multi-factor authentication API operation to enforce multi-factor authentication requirements for all user accounts within a specified domain.

listitem.para: Set the enforcement level to REQUIRED to make multi-factor authentication mandatory for accounts within a specified domain.
Set the enforcement level to OPTIONAL to make multi-factor authentication optional for all users.

section.para:
Administrators can update the domain-level enforcement setting from the API or the Cloud Control Panel. The following figure shows the API work flow for updating domain enforcement settings.
API workflow for domain-level enforcement of multi-factor authentication

The following example shows the API request to update domain enforcement settings for a domain. The example assumes the following credentials and account information: an authenticated user administrator with a valid admin token ($ADMIN_TOKEN) and the ID of the domain ($DOMAIN_ID) to update. Use the retrieve domains operation to retrieve the domain ID.

example.title: Update domain to require multi-factor authentication for all users: cURL JSON request

section.para: Successful requests return a HTTP 204 No Content message. To verify the change, submit a GET domain by id request, as shown in the following example.

example.title: Verify domain settings after update: cURL JSON request and response
example.programlisting: $ curl -X -i GET identity.api.rackspacecloud.com/v2.0/RAX-AUTH/domains/$DOMAIN_ID \ -H "Content-type: application/json" \ -H "X-Auth-Token: $ADMIN_AUTH_TOKEN" --verbose | python -m json tool

section.para: As soon as the domain enforcement level changes to REQUIRED, the Identity service revokes all tokens that were not obtained by using the multi-factor authentication flow. To regain account access, users who have not enabled multi-factor authentication can request a scoped mfa-setup token that they can use to add multi-factor authentication to their account.

Customize multi-factor authentication enforcement settings for specific users

section.title: Update user-level enforcement for multi-factor authentication
section.para: Rackspace Cloud Identity and user administrators can use customize the multi-factor enforcement level for specific users by using the update multi-factor authentication settings operation.

listitem.para: Set the enforcement level to REQUIRED to require multi-factor authentication on the account regardless of the domain level enforcement setting.
Set the enforcement level to OPTIONAL to allow the user to select or opt out of multi-factor authentication.
Set the enforcement level to DEFAULT to allow the user account to inherit the domain level enforcement setting.

section.para: Administrators can update the user-level enforcement setting from the API or the Cloud Control Panel. The following figure shows the API work flow for updating the user enforcement setting with state transitions.

figure.title: Workflow to set up a user account for multi-factor authentication

section.para: The following example assumes the following accounts and credentials: an authenticated User Administrator account with a valid authentication token and a user account within the same domain.

example.title: Require user to log in by using multi-factor authentication: cURL JSON request and response

screen.computeroutput: HTTP/1.1 204 No Content Vary: Accept, Accept-Encoding, X-Auth-Token

section.para: As soon as the user-level enforcement level changes to REQUIRED or if the value changes to DEFAULT and the domain-level enforcement setting is REQUIRED, the Identity service revokes all tokens for the user that were not obtained by using the multi-factor authentication process. Also, if the To regain account access, users can request for a scoped mfa-setup tokenthat they can use to update their account configuration.

The account user must submit another authentication request to retrieve a scoped authentication token that allows access to the Identity service to set up multi-factor authentication on the user account.

section.title: Request a scoped mfa-setup token to set up multi-factor authentication
section.para: To get account access, the user must request a scoped MFA-SETUP token that provides limited access to the Identity service for account configuration.

example.title: User authentication request for a scoped mfa-setup token: cURL JSON request and response

section.para: Note that the service catalog is not returned in the response. The MFA-SETUP token in the response provides users with limited account configuration capabillities (illustrated in the following figure) so that they can set up multi-factor authentication.

figure.title: Capabilities available with a scoped mfa-setup token

section.para: After receiving the scoped mfa-setup token, users can export it to an environment variable as shown in the following example, and use it to configure their account for multi-factor authentication via mobile phone.

note.para: As soon as the user has added a multi-factor authentication device to their account, the scoped mfa-setup token is revoked, and the user can follow the multi-factor authentication process to log in.
